title: How to Format a Blog Post (For Search Success)
description: Discover how exactly you should format your blog posts in order to get more engagement and search success.
content: Chris Haines Chris is an SEO director who has 10 years of experience in SEO, agency side. When not involved in SEO, he enjoys messing around with vintage synthesizers, walks on sandy beaches, and a good cup of tea. Get the week's best marketing content Email Subscription Subscribe Leave this field empty if you're human: Contents When you‚Äôre writing a blog post, it‚Äôs easy to overlook the formatting. But how exactly should you format your blog posts to get more engagement and search success?ContentsGet to the point, don‚Äôt waffleWhen it comes to writing the introduction, keep it simple, concise, and tailored to your audience.If you want a defined approach for formatting your introduction, you can use the Problem-Solution-Proof (PSP) introduction formula.Using the PSP formula means you can get straight to the core of the topic by outlining the problem, giving a solution, and providing proof of why your audience should trust you‚Äîall in just two paragraphs.It also means there‚Äôs space to put an image above the fold, making your post more visually engaging for visitors.Make it scannableOnce you‚Äôve perfected your introduction, it‚Äôs time to consider how to arrange the rest of the article.The reality is that many people do not read from start to finish anymore. A study by Nielson suggested that only 16% of its test users read an article word by word. So it‚Äôs important to make your articles scannable to maximize engagement on your blog. The easiest way to do this is to use headings or, more specifically, H1 tags and other <H> tags.Headings also have a secondary benefit, as they help to provide an SEO-friendly structure for your article.Here‚Äôs what it looks like in practice. You want to aim for a clear hierarchy.In my opinion, your headings should have two qualities:Individually, they should have an impact and catch the reader‚Äôs attention.Collectively, they need to form a logical outline and indicate the key elements of the article at a glance.In practice, it‚Äôs often a balancing act: You‚Äôll need to be able to structure posts in a logical, hierarchical way and also entice the reader to read on.Format for the dominant content typeGenerally speaking, a lot of content on the internet falls into these categories:List postsStep-by-step guidesBeginner‚Äôs guidesExpanded definitionReviewsFor this reason, before you create your written content, it‚Äôs a good idea to research what type of content is already ranking for your target keywords so that you can format it properly.This may seem like overkill, but you don‚Äôt want to waste time creating content in a format that readers are unlikely to engage with. So it pays to get it right from the start.For example, if we write a 2,000-word article on ‚Äúhow to tie a tie‚Äù and visitors are expecting a video, it‚Äôs unlikely our written content will ever get a chance to appear at the top of the SERP because it‚Äôs not the type of content our audience is looking for.To show you how quick it is to check for the dominant content type, let‚Äôs jump into Ahrefs‚Äô Keywords Explorer, plug in ‚Äúhow to tie a tie,‚Äù and scroll down to the SERP overview.We can see from this search that the top result is a video hosted on YouTube. That means in order to compete in this SERP, we‚Äôll probably need to create a video on this topic.With that said, let‚Äôs take a look at some of the most common written content types that you can easily format for.List postsList posts are very common, especially in certain niches where visitors are looking for inspiration or ideas. Let‚Äôs start by plugging in ‚Äúthings to do in capri‚Äù in Keywords Explorer. If we scroll down to the SERP overview, we can see that almost all of the results contain a number, meaning they are likely to be list posts.From this example, as there are so many list posts ranking on the first page for this query, we‚Äôll need to stick to the list post format in order to stand a chance of ranking on this SERP.Here‚Äôs an example of the format you can use for a list post:Step-by-step guidesLet‚Äôs now plug in another different keyword. I‚Äôve added ‚Äúpodcasting guide‚Äù into Keywords Explorer to see what we get.Although the SERP result titles contain numbers as well, we can see that the dominant content type at the top of the SERP is about providing step-by-step guides. TipSometimes, you‚Äôll need to click on the URLs and visit the webpage to double-check the content type.Here‚Äôs an example of the format you can use for a step-by-step guide:Beginner‚Äôs guidesLet‚Äôs take a look at another content type. I‚Äôve plugged the keyword ‚Äúchess basics‚Äù into the SERP overview.From my highlights, we can see that the title tags of these pages are aimed at beginners. If we wanted to create a beginner‚Äôs guide for a topic, the format of the post might look something like this:Expanded definitionAnother common type of content is the expanded definition. This type of content explains the meaning of a thing or concept before going into more detail about it.Let‚Äôs plug in ‚Äúlatte‚Äù into Keywords Explorer and scroll down to the SERP overview.In this example, we can see that the top result is asking what a latte is. We can use this format to build out a post on this topic.Another element you can add to an ‚Äúexpanded definition‚Äù format post is FAQs. Adding this section with schema can be a good combination. Here‚Äôs an example of some popular FAQs about H1 tags from our blog:ReviewsOne of the most popular content formats is the review format. This format is fairly self-explanatory‚Äîvisitors to your site are expecting the product or service to be reviewed.Let‚Äôs take a look at a ‚Äúreview‚Äù SERP in Keywords Explorer.This is one of the easier-to-spot formats, and you can see almost every SERP result title has the word ‚Äúreview‚Äù in it.When it comes to writing reviews, Google provides detailed guidance on how to write a good review, which you can read about below.Further readingWrite High Quality ReviewsFormatting specificsMany content creators know how to format content. But in the rush to produce content, it‚Äôs easy to let the quality of the formatting slide or omit it altogether.Here‚Äôs a reminder of what you should and shouldn‚Äôt do:Don‚Äôt make your article needlessly long‚Äîkeep it succinct and to the pointIf you are writing to reach a word count, then you are creating content wrong. You should really focus on writing the best blog post you can. Though, it‚Äôs useful to know how long different pages on the SERP are because it gives you a sense of the opportunity available. The best way to check is to use Keywords Explorer‚Äôs SERP overview, as it lists the word count of the top pages on the SERP.Using a tool like this, we can see that for this topic, the number #1 ranking article is the shortest article on the SERP. So if we hired a freelance writer to write a 4000-word blog post on ‚Äúwhat is a latte,‚Äù chances are, it would be too much.Use text formatting for emphasisBasic text formatting, like using bold, italic, or <a> links, is a good way to highlight certain parts of your content for search engines.Google‚Äôs John Muller had this to say about bolding text:Does bolding important points on a paragraph help the SEO? Yes it does. It does help us to better understand that paragraph or that page.John Mueller, Search Advocate GoogleUse a table of contents I mentioned making your blog posts scannable earlier on. In my opinion, there is no better way to do this than by adding a table of contents, as it summarizes your content in a few lines that users can click.Adding a table of contents is a good way to allow your page‚Äôs visitors to scan your content‚Äôs core topics quickly.It can also trigger sitelinks, which can potentially help you win even more organic clicks.TipIf you use WordPress, you can use a free plugin like Easy Table of Contents to add a table of contents to your blog posts automatically.Use internal linking to explain other conceptsInternal linking for SEO is one of the most powerful aspects of formatting a blog post, in my opinion. Check out our video and guides on how to do it below.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3tbDkc3k48EFurther readingWhat Are Internal Links?Internal Links for SEO: An Actionable GuideUse external links when linking to useful resourcesExternal links should be used more sparingly than internal links. But it‚Äôs good to link to relevant, trusted sources that help provide context for your content.Add an author bioAdding an author bio is a good way to provide legitimacy for your readers. If visitors to your site can see that the content is written by a real person, it adds to its authenticity.At Ahrefs, we have an author bio below every post with links to our social media profiles.Use images to enhance your content Generally speaking, it‚Äôs a good idea to add images to help convey more meaning to your content. It‚Äôs important because some SERPs will pull through images from your articles.Here‚Äôs an example where images from my blog post on website structure were pulled into the Google SERP:Use original, web-ready imagesWhen it comes to images, it‚Äôs easy to use a stock image. But a better idea is to use your own original images where possible. They also should ideally be ‚Äúweb ready.‚Äù This means using WEBP image formats for the best performance.When it comes to optimizing your images, you can also use alt text as part of your basic image optimization.Final thoughtsMany of the elements of formatting a blog post for search are not difficult. Yet surprisingly, many online publishers still don‚Äôt take the time to do it.Taking a structured approach to formatting can help your content stand out from the crowd and get it recognized on the SERPs.Got more questions?
